You're right. Amir's growth significantly impacts his relationships with other characters in the novel. Specifically, his relationships with his father Baba and his friend Hassan undergo significant changes as a result of his growth.

At the beginning of the novel, Amir is constantly seeking his father's approval and love but feels like he can never live up to his expectations. Baba sees Amir as weak and cowardly, which makes Amir feel insecure and worthless. However, as Amir grows and matures, he realizes that his father's expectations were misguided and that he had been wrong to see himself in such a negative light. He becomes more confident and assertive, and this newfound self-assurance allows him to confront his father and their misunderstandings more openly. Ultimately, their relationship becomes more honest, open, and loving.

Similarly, Amir's relationship with Hassan changes over the course of the novel. At the beginning of the story, Amir is jealous of Hassan's close relationship with his father and their friendship makes him feel even more inadequate. However, as Amir grows and matures, he realizes the deep bond that he shares with Hassan and the pain that he has caused him. He seeks redemption for his past mistakes and makes amends to Hassan, who ultimately forgives him for his past wrongdoings. This leads to a more profound and meaningful relationship between the two characters.

In short, Amir's growth allows him to confront the misunderstandings and conflicts in his relationships with Baba and Hassan more openly and honestly, leading to more profound and meaningful relationships in the end.
